reporting-org.narrative: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

title.narrative: Towards an Indonesia free of Tuberculosis

description.narrative: Indonesia - Tuberculosis - Central Board of ‘Aisyiyah - AISYIYA. This program has the following goals: To reduce TB related morbidity and mortality in thirty four provinces of Indonesia, with strong contribution of health and community systems. To halt and reduce drug resistant TB incidence among new TB cases at community. To reduce TB/HIV related mortality. The objectives of this program are: To achieve universal access to prevention of TB infection and care, support, and treatment of TB for key affected populations at higher risk, people living with HIV and general population through TB program leaderships strengthening at national and sub-national level. Increase detection and notification of all forms of TB From 129/100,000 pop in 2015 to 240/100,000 pop by 2020. Ensure treatment success of 90% for drug-sensitive TB treatment in NTP and non NTP providers by 2020.. Ensure universal access to diagnosis and treatment for drug-resistant TB by 2020 (55% of estimated MDR cases are diagnosed & treated by 2020 and 80% by 2025)

title.narrative: DOTS-other 1: Number of suspected TB cases referred by trained community cadres
MDR TB-other 1: Number of MDR-TB patients supported by CSO for adherence to treatment and default tracing in selected sites

TB/HIV-other 3: Number and percentage of TB patients with known HIV status - TB patients registered during the reporting period who had an HIV test result recorded in the TB register among the total number of TB patients referred by the community cadres
Percentage of notified TB cases, all forms, contributed by non-NTP providers - community referrals
Number of notified TB cases (all forms) contributed by non-national TB program providers – community referrals
TCP-Other 1: Percentage of bacteriologically confirmed TB patients whose household contacts screened for TB

DOTS-other 2: Percentage of TB cases, all forms, bacteriologically confirmed plus clinically diagnosed, successfully treated (cured plus treatment completed) among all TB cases registered for treatment during a specified period - community referrals
